subject: Re: [junit] Is this approach to mock objects too complex?

messageBody:
On Friday 16 July 2004 03:59 am, kk_oop wrote:
> Hi.  I was just reading an article about a novel way of implementing
> mock objects using an anonymous inner class.  The article is at:
>
> http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-mocktest.html

This is really novel. Folks have been using this approach for quite some
time. I have used it for years, and still do in the cases where a mock
library is too heavy-weight.

> I find, though, that when I try to run the sample code in listings 5
> and 6 through JUnit, I get a null pointer exception.

Where?

> So now I'm wondering two things:
>
> 1- Does anyone see why this code wouldn't work?

Not at first glance.

> 2- Does this approach to Mock classes add unnecessary complexity?
> Perhaps I'd just be better off using a regular ol' derived class
> instead of an anonymous inner class.  The catch is that the regular
> ol' derived class would need to be passed into the class being tested
> as a constructor parameter instead of being contained completely by
> the class being tested.

As I implied before, this doesn't neccessarily add complexity. In fact, I
often use it to avoid the complexity of a mock framework. YMMV.

One thing to watch out for is duplication. If you find yourself creating the
same types of support classes as nested classes over and over again it's a
sign that you need to pull that support class out into a top-level (as the
article suggests with MockTransaction).
